slides.title: Definition
bullets: Bioluminescence is the production and emission of light by living organisms.
It occurs when a chemical reaction inside the organism produces energy in the form of visible light.
Unlike fluorescence, bioluminescence does not require external light sources.

slides.title: Key Chemicals
bullets: Luciferin: the molecule that produces light when oxidized.
Luciferase: the enzyme that catalyzes the oxidation of luciferin.
ATP: energy source for some bioluminescent reactions.

slides.title: Functions in Marine Life
bullets: Camouflage (Counter-illumination): Some organisms, like certain squid, produce light on their bellies to match the faint light from above, making them less visible to predators below.
Attraction: Anglerfish have bioluminescent lures to attract prey. Similarly, some jellyfish use light to lure small fish.
Communication: Certain species of marine worms and shrimp use light signals to find mates or coordinate group behaviors.
Defense: Some squids and small crustaceans release bioluminescent fluids to distract predators, allowing escape.

slides.title: Examples of Bioluminescent Organisms
bullets: Firefly Squid (Watasenia scintillans): Found in Japan, glows blue in large swarms, attracting tourists and predators alike.
Deep-sea Anglerfish: Uses a luminescent lure to attract prey in the pitch-black deep ocean.
Dinoflagellates: Microscopic plankton that glow in waves when disturbed, causing "sea sparkle".
Jellyfish: Many deep-sea species have bioluminescent patterns for communication or defense.

slides.title: Interesting Facts
bullets: Bioluminescence is more common in deep-sea environments than shallow waters because sunlight cannot reach the depths.
The color of bioluminescent light is typically blue or green because these wavelengths travel farthest in water.
Some fish can control the intensity and duration of their glow, flashing patterns to signal warnings or confuse predators.
Scientists are studying bioluminescence for applications in medical imaging, environmental monitoring, and bioengineering.
